responses:
theorem Topology.P1_iff_frontier_subset_closure_interior {X : Type*}
    [TopologicalSpace X] {A : Set X} :
    Topology.P1 A ↔ frontier A ⊆ closure (interior A) := by
  constructor
  · intro hP1
    exact
      Topology.frontier_subset_closure_interior_of_P1 (A := A) hP1
  · intro hFront
    -- We show `P1 A` from the assumed inclusion on the frontier.
    unfold Topology.P1
    intro x hxA
    by_cases hInt : x ∈ interior A
    ·
      -- If `x` is in `interior A`, the result is immediate.
      exact (subset_closure : interior A ⊆ closure (interior A)) hInt
    ·
      -- Otherwise, `x` lies on the frontier of `A`.
      have hxFront : x ∈ frontier A := by
        -- `x` is in `closure A` because `A ⊆ closure A`.
        have hxCl : x ∈ closure A := subset_closure hxA
        -- Combine the facts `x ∈ closure A` and `x ∉ interior A`.
        have : x ∈ closure A ∧ x ∉ interior A := And.intro hxCl hInt
        simpa [frontier] using this
      -- Apply the frontier inclusion to conclude.
      exact hFront hxFront

theorem Topology.P1_singleton_of_discrete {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X]
    [DiscreteTopology X] {x : X} :
    Topology.P1 ({x} : Set X) := by
  -- Expand the definition of `P1`.
  unfold Topology.P1
  intro y hy
  -- In a discrete space every set is open; in particular `{x}` is open,
  -- hence its interior is itself.
  have hInt : interior ({x} : Set X) = {x} :=
    (isOpen_discrete ({x} : Set X)).interior_eq
  -- From `y ∈ {x}` we deduce `y ∈ interior {x}` using the equality above.
  have hMemInt : y ∈ interior ({x} : Set X) := by
    simpa [hInt] using hy
  -- Every point of a set is contained in the closure of that set.
  exact (subset_closure hMemInt)
